sentence: Stock indexes in the U.S. added to the day's declines by the close on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average shedding 181 points and the Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500 also retreating after economic data raised speculation about the chance of more interest-rate increases this year.
The benchmarks ran lower in late trading but just managed to close ahead of lows reached on May 13.
The S&P 500's consumer staples and utilities sectors fell 2% and 1.8% respectively, leading all 10 groups lower as energy just nudged into negative territory by the close.
All but three of the 30 Dow components fell, with Home Depot ( HD ) down 3% even after reporting better-than-expected earnings.
The consumer price index in April topped estimates at 0.4% month-on-month, while industrial production accelerated by 0.7% in April, beating projections for a gain of 0.2%.
March, however, was revised downward to negative 0.9% from an initial negative 0.6%.
Capacity utilization was at 75.4% in April from 74.9% in March, beating estimates for 74.9% in utility output.
And housing starts rose 6.6% last month to a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 1.172 million from an upwardly revised 1.099 million in March, and above estimates for a gain of 4.2%.
On Wednesday, the Federal Open Market Committee will release minutes from its meeting in April, with investors set to examine the report for clues on whether a hike in June might be on the cards.
